questions.question: Despite of having a headache, I enjoyed the movie.
questions.description: Write despite or in spite of.

questions.question: If you will happen to see Jane, ask her to phone me.
questions.description: The correct sentence is: If you happen to see Jane, ask her to phone me.

questions.question: Broadly to speaking, teachers are overworked and underpaid.
questions.description: The correct expression is broadly speaking.

questions.question: Sometimes people often behave strangely when they are abroad.
questions.description: Often and sometimes are both adverbs of frequency. Use only one of them in a clause.

questions.question: Although I admit that junk food is bad for health, but I don’t think that it should be banned.
questions.description: The conjunctions although and but mean the same. Use only one of them in a clause.

questions.question: Since the day was very hot therefore I didn’t go out.
questions.description: The word since is used to give the reason and therefore is used to show the effect/result. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: Because she wanted to win the first prize so she worked hard.
questions.description: We need only one conjunction to connect two clauses.

questions.question: He is a man who dare to say what he thinks.
questions.description: When dare is used as a modal auxiliary it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: She is richer than compared to ninety percent of her neighbors.
questions.description: Richer than is enough to express this idea.

questions.question: You need not to pay for that call.
questions.description: When need is used as a modal auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: I can’t make the dish washer to work.
questions.description: Make + object is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: Most things seem to be made of from plastic these days.
questions.description: We use made of when we identify the material used to make something.
